I've managed several crawls over the .is TLD.  In my experience the default=
 
politeness rules
delay-factor: 5.0
max-delay-ms: 5000
min-delay-ms: 500
h=
ave proved more then adequate except in one isolated case where (since we 
=
use host based politeness) one domain with many virtual sub-domains (blogs =

actually) got swamped. But that is really a seperate issue (and might not
=
affect
IP based politeness. The solution in that instance was to force queu=
e 
assignments to merge all sub-domains with the politness queue of the mai=
n
domain.
 
In fact I have run more aggressive crawls without complaints. M=
ost of the 
complaints I do get are because of Heritrix's aggressive link e=
xtractions
that
leads to 404 content (often soft 404) that's showing up in =
server logs.
 
I've never imposed a per-server bandwidth limitation. The on=
ly reason why 
you might want to do that (that I can think off relating to =
crawl
politeness) 
is if you are crawling personal domains where people hav=
e limited bandwidth 
(in that once exceeded the service provider blocks acc=
ess). Otherwise, 
adjusing the politness factors seems more appropriate. (T=
hat's just my
opinion 
of course, there may also be reasons relating to cra=
wling strategies 
- balancing - for doing this, but that is another subject=
).
 
I would be very interested in hearing exactly what the complaints you =
have 
recieved where? 
 
Also, I know that our activities (National Library=
 doing legal deposit)
have met with a lot of goodwill so I'm sure that many=
 site admins that might
complain to some random harvester, are tolerating u=
s.
 
- Kris
 

-----Original Message-----
From: archive-crawler@yahoogroups=
.com
[mailto:archive-crawler@yahoogroups.com] On Behalf Of Karl Wright
Sent=
: 13. desember 2005 16:24
To: archive-crawler@yahoogroups.com
Subject: [arc=
hive-crawler] Niceness numbers


Guys,

You do a lot of Heritrix crawls, co=
rrect?  Do the default document wait 
times and maximum per-server bandwidt=
h accurately reflect "best 
practices" in this area?  If so, you should kno=
w we've needed to reduce 
the per-server bandwidth to not annoy some sites.=
..  If not, I'd love to 
hear what successful people are using for these pa=
rameters.

Karl Wright
